title: Does every truth you accept set you more free? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. A truth makes you free only if you accept it. The freedom comes with acceptation of any truth or reality you are involved in. In the acceptance of the truth you are no more ignorance and you are free. Think in this terms: you love playing with fire, you love to feel its heat around you but you get burnt all the time. You feel pain but you are so involved emotionally with the fire that you do not understand that the fire is the thing which make you suffer. You are blind. Recognizing and accepting that the fire is the bringer of pleasure and pain both makes you free, because now it is your choice, now you know. Your suffering is no more blind and you have control over it. Then you choose. The will was not free, was blind wanting the fire without knowing the fire. Now the will is free, it is a choice.

A truth is only a truth if it is true. However we have no way of determining for sure that anything is true.  We can only poke at it. That's all that the null hypothesis helps us do.Revelation is someone's story.  Convinced maybe, but a story, still. Language only works in the real world if it has the capacity for ambiguity, otherwise it would freeze like ice. So where would we get to if we unpacked your question in terms of what the words mean? My take:'truth' = dictum = dogma; a policy commitment'accept' = commit to?/ act as if real'free' = untroubled?   I've been told that 'grass' has a similar impact.   <3  ^  ^

Not precisely. It is true that a correct model of reality makes you more effective.  I am not altogether sure whether truth is countable. I'd much rather think in terms of how precise and complete your image of something is and if you see it in the right perspective or not. If you manage to do that well, you can be said to be close to the truth. In that case, working to better something or to stop something bad from happening, you will not be automatically successful but at least you will not be hindered by a wrong image of things.

Truth by it's very nature is simply information that can be relied upon. It does not set you free or confine you. It allows one to make decisions based upon fact. Being free is not relevant. Sometimes the truth hurts and sometimes it warms your soul.
Truth set you free. But there is not two or three of it. "Every truth" means that you are considering mental descriptions of reality as being truthful, and they aren't.
How does "I" <- connecting -> "truth" set me free?  That's just one more fetter.   Perhaps an insight disconnects a truth, and then I will be getting freed.

It is not knowing different true things or facts that sets you free. The fraise 'the truth will set you free' refers to you your self being a truthfull person. That will go a long way to setting you free. From the inner turmoil that we all face in one way or another.
No; not for me. I feel completely free even knowing I am utterly ignorant.
